Pediatric asthma more likely near Logan Airport

Does living close to the airport increase the risk of childhood asthama? According to logan airport health study final report, children who live in neighborhoods bordering Logan International Airport are as much as four times more likely to wheeze, experience shortness of breath, and exhibit other signs of undiagnosed asthma compared with children who live farther away.

By Sierra Sun


Pediatric asthma rate is much higher in Boston

Annual Average Crude Rates of Hospital Admission for Asthma per 10,000 People (aged 0 - 14)


From the chart above, you can tell that Boston have much higher rate of hospital admission due to asthma.

Comparison of prevalence of pediatric asthma between Boston schools and Massachusetts schools


From the chart above, we can know that Boston students have much higher rate of asthma comparing to whole state students. Boston is home to a disproportionate number of these children. During the 2014-2015 school year, 2,706 of Boston’s elementary and middle school students had asthma – nearly 14.1% of students!



Distribution of pediatric asthma

Median prevalence of pediatric asthma among boston schools


From the map, we can know that Boston students inside the region of Chinatown, have much higher asthma prevalence than other region. Meanwhile, the asthma prevalence is growing along with the time.



Asthma triggers -- Air pollutants

For many of these studies, ambient concentrations of PM2.5 and the gaseous co-pollutants (i.e., CO, sulfur dioxide (SO2), NO2 and ozone) are highly correlated with certain health outcomes.

Recently promulgated ambient air standards by the US EPA for nitrogen dioxide (NO2) (US EPA, 2008) and SO2 (US EPA, 2008a) are based on studies that have demonstrated respiratory health effects from short- term exposure to NO2 and SO2, including airway inflammation in healthy people; increased respiratory symptoms in people with asthma, and increased visits to emergency departments and hospital admissions for respiratory illnesses.

Numerous scientific studies over the past 20 years have linked PM exposure to respiratory health effects, including aggravated asthma.
